My Story

Today, I’m a UX designer passionate about researching and creating accessible solutions for hardware and physical products. You may be suprised, I actually started my educational journey in mechanical engineering.


From a young age, I liked getting my hands dirty with whatever I was working on; from legos to cars, I built things. So, it made sense to pursue a degree mechanical engineering.

I restored a 1979 Ford Bronco. Check it out on instagram!

Mechanical engineering (ME) gave me great opportunities, like two internships at Whirlpool. There I designed a patented solution for top-load washing machines. I enjoyed the experience of being able to engage with the development of a product.

Dual wall system that increased capacity in top-load washing machines. Awarded Patent US20170030000AI. Read patent

When I returned to classes in the fall of 2015, the ME major focused on maximizing theoretical efficiencies and lowering manufacturing costs, and those didn’t capture my interests. Instead, I became enthralled in the story behind a product. That’s when I began to learn about UX.

Presenting mockups for Helping Home application with my Teach Access team.

UX design is an amazing platform that allows me to create meaningful and relevant experiences for people. Once I started pursuing a degree in UX, I fell in love with the incredible influence a human-centered approach has on improving every aspect of a product. I learned about accessibility, usability, and how meaningful a career in Accessibility can be.

Trying out the Magic Leap One at the 2019 XR Symposium

Today, I still get my hands dirty. Instead of working with legos and combustion engines, I incorporate my varied experience to solve accessibility challenges. I live to be curious, empathetic, and supportive. On cross-functional teams, I strive to empower others so there are no limits what we can accomplish together!

Let's talk!
